1.title: Million-Dollar School Board

episode of.title: Postcards from the Great Divide (TV Series 2016)

1.plot: A humble school board race in suburban Denver becomes a proxy battle between national political groups like the Koch Brothers and the teachers' union, as even down ballot races become nationalized.

2.title: The Big Sort

episode of.title: Postcards from the Great Divide (TV Series 2016)

2.plot: There's a political self-sorting process that is happening across America. Blue voters are choosing to live in "creative-class" urban oases, as red voters remain in rural areas. Minnesota native Aaron Spading, conservative church-goer turned far-left Powderhorn Park resident, guides us as we explore one of those blue-dots-in-a-sea-of-red. Meetings with family and old neighbors illustrate just how deep the political gulf between people can be, but the film ends on a hopeful note; where there is dialogue, there can still be community.

3.title: Gibraltar May Tumble

episode of.title: Postcards from the Great Divide (TV Series 2016)

3.plot: Democrats used to be competitive in both cities and the countryside, but partisanship has changed things. It's now getting harder and harder to find Democrats in rural areas across the US, but especially in the South. Are the partisans of Western Kentucky the last of this dying breed? We travel to the politically raucous annual Fancy Farm Picnic to find out.

4.title: Whatever Happened to Wisconsin Nice?

episode of.title: Postcards from the Great Divide (TV Series 2016)

4.plot: Once the poster child for bipartisan practical politics, the Badger State has become an ideological battleground in recent years. What happened to the middle?

5.title: The Giant Still Sleeps

episode of.title: Postcards from the Great Divide (TV Series 2016)

5.plot: Pundits seem convinced that a purple Texas is just around the corner due to its burgeoning Latino population, yet the state gets redder and redder. One factor is that Latino turnout remains low.

6.title: Blue Wind on a Red Prairie

episode of.title: Postcards from the Great Divide (TV Series 2016)

6.plot: Nebraska is one of the reddest of red states. It hasn't voted statewide for a Democrat for President in over fifty years. So how can the minority party rise from the mat and become relevant in state politics?

7.title: Post-Obama Drama

episode of.title: Postcards from the Great Divide (TV Series 2016)

7.plot: n 2008 and '12 African-Americans in Florida turned out in record numbers even when voting hours and registration rules were tightened. What are the challenges with the black electorate that Hillary Clinton faced in this must-win state?

8.title: Purple Reign

episode of.title: Postcards from the Great Divide (TV Series 2016)

8.plot: In the fight to win control at the state level, Republicans have reached an historic high, capturing thirty-one legislatures in the past several years. Now the Republicans are looking for more, even in a left-leaning state like Washington.

9.title: Swinging Las Vegas

episode of.title: Postcards from the Great Divide (TV Series 2016)

9.plot: Nevada used to be a deep red state, but things have changed. Thousands of Latinos have moved in, many to work in the gaming industry, and the state is turning purple. What can the state GOP do in the year of Trump to get more Latino votes?

imdb.plot outline: Postcards from the Great Divide is a series of nine short documentaries produced by leading American independent filmmakers that are being released in a digital partnership between PBS' Election 2016 initiative and The Washington Post. The series travels to locations across the U.S. to examine the nation's partisan divide. Stories are told from the viewpoint of voters and activists. Different episodes explore how changing demographics and political self-sorting will continue to have a profound effect on American politics for years to come.
imdb.title: Postcards from the Great Divide
akas: Postcards from the Great Divide (United States)
plot: _Postcards from the Great Divide_ (qv) is a series of nine short documentaries produced by leading American independent filmmakers that are being released in a digital partnership between PBS' Election 2016 initiative and The Washington Post. The series travels to locations across the U.S. to examine the nation's partisan divide. Stories are told from the viewpoint of voters and activists. Different episodes explore how changing demographics and political self-sorting will continue to have a profound effect on American politics for years to come.::Joe Winston
